sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Acute: 2-dose regimen: 1000 mg IV as single dose, followed by 500 mg IV 1 week later

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment, CrCl less than 30 mL/min and not receiving hemodialysis: 750 mg IV infusion followed by 375 mg IV infusion 1 week later
  • hemodialysis: no adjustment necessary and may be administered without regard to timing of hemodialysis
  • hepatic impairment, mild (Child-Pugh class A): no adjustment necessary
  • hepatic impairment, moderate to severe (Child-Pugh class B or C): use with caution.

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Acute
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Bacteremia, Catheter-related

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Gastrointestinal:
  • -- patients who experience diarrhea following dalbavancin use, including occurrence more than 2 months after administration, should be evaluated for clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) and appropriate treatment (eg, discontinuation of dalbavancin use, antibiotic treatment of C difficile, surgical evaluation, fluid and electrolyte management, protein supplementation) should be implemented if suspected or confirmed
  • Hepatic:
  • -- ALT elevation greater than 3 times ULN has been reported
  • Immunologic:
  • -- serious hypersensitivity (anaphylactic) and skin reactions have been reported; discontinue use if an allergic reaction occurs
  • -- give cautiously to patients with a history of hypersensitivity to glycopeptides because of possible cross-sensitivity
  • Other:
  • -- infusion-related reactions, including flushing of the upper body, urticaria, pruritus, or rash, may occur; administer in a dilute solution over at least 30 minutes and stopping or slowing the infusion time may lessen the reactions

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Constipation (18.2%), Diarrhea (4.4%), Nausea (5.5%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (4.7%)
Serious
  • Gastrointestinal:Clostridium difficile colitis (Less than 2%), Gastrointestinal hemorrhage (Less than 2%)
  • Hepatic:Alkaline phosphatase raised (Less than 2%), ALT/SGPT level raised (0.8%), Aminotransferase abnormal, Increased (Less than 2%), Hepatotoxicity (Less than 2%)
  • Other:Infusion reaction (Less than 2%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Dalbavancin is a semisynthetic lipoglycopeptide antibacterial agent inhibits cell wall peptidoglycan cross-linking by binding to the terminal of the D-alanyl-D-alaine pentapeptide chain in nascent peptidoglycan. Even though the mechanism of action is similar between dalbavancin and vancomycin, some vancomycin-resistant enterocci and staphylococci with intermediate sensitivity to glycopeptides remain sensitive to dalbavancin.

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono: Not affected by cytochrome P450 substrates, inhibitors, inducers or selected concomitant medications

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: 20% unchanged
  • Renal: 33% unchanged
  • Dialyzable: Yes, less than 6%
  • Total body clearance: 0.0473 L/hr

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • reconstitute with sterile water for injection; to avoid foaming, swirl to dissolve; do not shake
  • dilute in D5W to a final concentration of 1 to 5 mg/mL; total time from reconstitution to administration should not exceed 48 hours
  • administer over 30 minutes; rapid administration may cause flushing, urticaria, pruritus, or rash; stopping or slowing the infusion will lessen these reactions
  • flush IV line before and after infusion with D5W; do not use NS, precipitation may occur
  • do not infuse concomitantly with other medications or electrolytes

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement in acute bacterial skin and skin structure infections is indicative of efficacy
  • diarrhea; may indicate overgrowth of Clostridium difficile; may occur at late as 2 months following therapy discontinuation
  • hypersensitivity reactions including anaphylaxis; increased risk in patients with a history of glycopeptide allergy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn patient that serious allergic reactions may occur and require immediate medical attention.
  • Side effects may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, rash, or itching.
  • Instruct patient to report severe watery or bloody diarrhea.
  • Advise patient of the importance for completing the entire course of therapy.
